intro: Maresia lacera, commonly known as the brittleleaf mallow, is a flowering plant native to the tropical regions of Africa and the Middle East. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its soft, hairy leaves and showy, pink or white flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, well-drained soils and thrives in sunny to partially shaded environments. Its leaves are thin and fragile, giving it the common name "brittleleaf," while its flowers bloom in clusters during the rainy season. Maresia lacera is sometimes cultivated for its ornamental value due to its attractive foliage and blooms.
